lesson.title: Strings & Lists, Part 1
lesson.summary: Learn to work with strings and lists in your Python code.

conf.replCommand: cd /home/workspace; while true; do python3 mad.py; sleep 2; done

atoms.text:
This is the actual output of a program that you will write at the end of this lesson.

This program has a collection of templates for building sentences, as well as collections of nouns (such as "iceberg" and "snake") and verbs (such as "caught" and "hacked"). The templates for sentences look like this:
```
The {{noun}} {{verb}} the {{noun}}.
```
Then the program puts together a sentence by substituting random nouns and verbs into the template, creating masterpieces of modern English composition such as:
```text
The iceberg hacked the snake.
```
How will you do this? _With a heck of a lot of strings._

# Variables vs. literals

Earlier in the course, we pointed out how Python treats a piece of code like `"blue"` (with quotes) differently from a piece of code like `blue` (without quotes). Let's play around with this ...

question.prompt:
Start up the Python interactive interpreter (a.k.a. Python interactive mode) in the terminal on your computer. Then, try simply entering the word *cake*:

```bash
>>> cake
```

What happens?

answers.text: It displays `'cake'` on a new line.
It displays `'yummy'` on a new line.
It displays `NameError: name 'cake' is not defined`.
It displays `SyntaxError: can't assign to literal`.

question.prompt:
Now, try it again, but put the word inside quotes:

```bash
>>> "cake"
```

What happens?

answers.text: It displays `'cake'` on a new line.
It displays `'yummy'` on a new line.
It displays `NameError: name 'cake' is not defined`.
It displays `SyntaxError: can't assign to literal`.

question.prompt:
Now try running these two lines:

```bash
>>> cake = "yummy"
>>> cake
```

What happens?

answers.text: It displays `'cake'` on a new line.
It displays `'yummy'` on a new line.
It displays `NameError: name 'cake' is not defined`.
It displays `SyntaxError: can't assign to literal`.

question.prompt:
Now try running this line:

```bash
>>> "cake" = "yummy"
```

What happens?

answers.text: It displays `'cake'` on a new line.
It displays `'yummy'` on a new line.
It displays `NameError: name 'cake' is not defined`.
It displays `SyntaxError: can't assign to literal`.

atoms.text: OK, so what's going on here? Just looking at the code by itself, it's not clear how `cake` is different from `"cake"`‚Äîand that's because the difference has to do with stuff that is happening behind the scenes in memory, where you can't see it. Let's have a look ...

complex_prompt.text:
Here's some code:

```python
amy = turtle.Turtle()
amy.color("blue")
distance = 50
amy.forward(distance)
amy.right(90)
```

Which of these pieces of the code are **variable names** (a.k.a. **identifiers**) and which are **literals**?

atoms.text: One of the most important parts of learning to program, is learning how the words you see in your code are related to data in memory. Learning to recognize which pieces of code are *literals* and which are *variable names* is a good example of this‚Äîand a key skill that you're now developing!

# More complex strings

We've seen how we can print out a simple string:

```python
print("Hello world!")
```

To do this, we simply put the text we want to print inside quotes (to show Python that it is a *string*).

But what if we want to print something more interesting‚Äîlike some text that already has quotes in it:

```text
To quote my favorite author, "let's go on an adventure!"
```

question.prompt:
Would it work if we just took the whole thing and put it inside a `print` call? Go ahead and try it!

```bash
>>> print(To quote my favorite author, "let's go on an adventure!")
```

What happens?

answers.text: It works and prints out the text without any problems.
It prints out the text, but in a mixed-up order.

question.prompt:
OK, let's try putting the whole thing in quotes, to see if that fixes it!

```bash
>>> print("To quote my favorite author, "let's go on an adventure!"")
```
What happens?

answers.text: It works and prints out the text without any problems.
It prints out the text, but in a mixed-up order.

atoms.text: Clearly, if we want to be able to handle more interesting strings‚Äîlike strings that have quotes in them‚Äîwe're going to need some new tools!

That was a lot! Karl went over:

* Single quotes `'` vs. double quotes `"`
* The newline character `\n`
* The escape character `\`
* Triple quotes `"""`

Let's get some practice with all of these.

complex_prompt.text:
Here are some different attempts at printing the following:

> That's John's pizza.

Which of these would work, and which would give an error?

atoms.text: **Hint:** If you look again at the code above, notice how the syntax highlighting can help you see where Python thinks a string begins and ends!

complex_prompt.text:
Here's another:

> She said, "It's lovely."

Which of these would work, and which would give an error?

How about this one?

>This message  
>is on two lines!

concepts.text:
```python
print("This message
is on two lines!")
```

```python
print("""This message
is on two lines!""")
```

tasks: Be sure that it prints to multiple lines, just like the text shown above.
Only use one `print` statement.
Print the whole thing without any errors.
atoms.description:
In the terminal below, see if you can print the following:

>"Is it very long?" Alice asked, for she had heard a good deal of poetry that day.
>
>"It's long," said the Knight, "but it's very, very beautiful."

You can do this using only *one* `print` statement.

To run your code, open a new terminal and enter:
```bash
python3 strings.py
```

atoms.text:
----

‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert!

 **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----

## Solution

Here's one way to do it:

```python
print('"Is it very long?" Alice asked, for she had heard a good deal of poetry that day.\n\n"It\'s long," said the Knight, "but it\'s very, very beautiful."')
```
**Note:** The above line of code is very long, so you may need to scroll to the right to see the whole thing.

Notice that this uses:
* Single quotes to surround the whole string
* The escape character `\` to take care of the single quotes that are inside the string
* The newline character `\n` to break the story to multiple lines

Another approach would be to simply enclose the whole thing in triple quotes:

```python
print("""
"Is it very long?" Alice asked, for she had heard a good deal of poetry that day.

"It's long," said the Knight, "but it's very, very beautiful."
""")
```

## Triple quotes`"""`, yes. Quadruple quotes `""""`, no!
Notice that in our solution above, we put the triple quotes `"""` on separate lines from the rest of the string. We did that partly to make the code more readable, but also because we wanted to avoid a series of four quotes: `""""`.

question.prompt:
Here's another way we might have tried to do it:
```python
print(""""Is it very long?" Alice asked, for she had heard a good deal of poetry that day.

"It's long," said the Knight, "but it's very, very beautiful."""")
```
Copy this into the workspace and see what happens when you run it!

answers.text: It works fine, just like the other version.
It throws an error‚Äî`TypeError: Incorrect data type.`
It throws an error‚Äî`SyntaxError: EOL while scanning string literal.`

atoms.text:
The trouble is with the series of four quotes `""""` at the end of the string. Python sees the **first three of these** as a signal that it has reached the end of the string‚Äîso when it then runs into the fourth quote, it thinks we're starting a new string. But then we never close that new string, and that's what causes the error.

If you're curious, you can read more about this issue in [this Stack Overflow post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48631068/why-in-python-3-do-quadruple-quotes-produce-a-syntax-error).

complex_prompt.text:
Below are some different things you can try in your terminal with the `len` function.

As you try them, keep these questions in mind:
* Do spaces count when calculating length?
* Can you assign a string to a variable, and then use `len` on the variable?
* Can you get the length of an integer?

Like Kelly mentioned, you can also use `len` with lists.

Give these a try and see what you get:

atoms.title: Too long for SMS
tasks: Add your code inside the `too_long` function definition.
When you're ready to test it, open a new terminal and run `python3 toolong.py`.
When you pass `too_long` a short string, it should return `False`.
When you pass `too_long` a long string, it should return `True`
atoms.description:
SMS messages (and old-school Twitter posts) are limited to 140 characters. In the workspace below (or in your own terminal, if you prefer), write a function called `too_long` that tells whether  a string is too long to be sent in a single SMS message.

You'll see that we added some code to help test your function (with a short string and a long string).

atoms.text:
----
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----

### Solution: Too long for SMS

Here's one way to do it:

```python
def too_long(s):
    length = len(s)
    if length > 140:
        return True
    else:
        return False
```

Here's another one:

```python
def too_long(s):
    return len(s) > 140
```

This one may not be as intuitive yet. Consider that `len(s) > 140` is an expression that will evaluate to either `True` or `False`. So this one line of code does basically the same thing as the five lines you see in the other version!

----

### üëæ Emoji in my strings?

*It's more likely than you think.*

Python strings aren't just limited to characters that appear on an English-language keyboard. Characters from other languages and writing systems can appear in Python strings. So can special symbols such as emoji:

```python
>>> print("Snakes! üêçüêçüêç")
Snakes! üêçüêçüêç
```
There is a Python module called `unicodedata` that lets you look up characters by name, including emoji:

```python
>>> import unicodedata
>>> unicodedata.lookup("snake")
'üêç'
>>> unicodedata.lookup("cat")
'üêà'
```

Emoji are usually wider on screen than letters or numbers; in a monospaced font they usually take up the space of two characters. They also take up more computer memory. But the length of a Python string depends only on the number of characters in it, _not_ on what kind of characters they are:

```python
>>> len("üêç")
1
>>> len("üêçüêçüêç")
3
>>> len("Ëõá = üêç")
5
```

# Looping over lists

When you were working with turtles, you used lists with `for` loops. To make sure the concept is fresh in your mind, here's an example you can try in your terminal:

tasks: Run this loop in the terminal.

atoms.text:
Each time this loop runs, one of the items in the list will get assigned to the `thing` variable, and then printed out. So by the time the loop has finished running, you'll see each of the items from the list printed out:

```text
some
list
of
things
```

When we use a list with a loop, we refer to it as "looping over a list". But lists aren't the only thing you can loop over ...
# Looping over strings
You can also loop over strings, and you do so in exactly the same way. Here's an example you can try for yourself:

question.prompt:
Give this a try in your terminal, and see what gets printed out:

```text
>>> for thing in "Hello!":
...     print(thing)
... 
```

Based on the results, how many times do you think the loop ran? (Put another way, how many times did the line `print(thing)` run?)

atoms.text:
When you ran the above loop, you should have seen this in your terminal:

```text
H
e
l
l
o
!
```

When we loop over a string, the loop runs one time for each character in that string. So this loop ran six times, and each time it ran, it assigned the next character in the string to the `thing` variable.

Actually, `thing` is not a great name for that variable. Since the variable gets assigned characters, we might call it `character` or maybe `ch` for short:

```python
for ch in "Hello!":
    print(ch)
```

This ability to loop over the characters in a string is very handy. For example, if we combine this with an `if` test, we can check all of the letters in a string‚Äîand have a certain block of code only run when a particular character is detected.

Here's a (silly) example:

```python
for ch in "Hello!":
    print(ch)
    if ch == "!":
        print("I'm excited too!!!")
```

tasks: If there is a `?` in the `message`, then print `Sense much curiosity in you, I do.`
If there is a `!` in the `message`, then print `Enthusiastic, you are.`
To try it out, open a new terminal and run `python3 looping.py`.
atoms.positive_feedback: The code is strong with this one.
atoms.description:
Here's another silly example‚Äîin the workspace below, you'll see there's code that gets input from the user and stores it in a variable called `message`.

Complete the code so that it checks the `message` for exclamation marks `!` (like above) and also question marks `?`, and prints a different message depending on which one it finds.

atoms.text:
----
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----
OK, now let's look at some less silly examples!

# Counting things (1/2)

Here's our goal on this page:
> Write some code that takes a string and counts the number of times a particular character occurs in that string.

For example, if we picked the string `bonobos` and the letter `o`, then the result should be `3`.

We can accomplish this task using a `for` loop and an `if` test. It might look something like this:

```python
for ch in "bonobos":
    if ch == "o":
        # Increase the count by one
```

We loop over the string, checking each character. While we do this, we keep a running total, or count, of how many times we've seen the letter `o`. Or put another way, `if` we see an `o`, we increase the count by `1`.

But how do we do that?

question.prompt:
The trick is to use code that looks like this:

```python
>>> n = 1
>>> n = n + 1
>>> n
```

Run this in the Python interactive interpreter. What do you get?

atoms.text:
So what exactly is happening with this code?

```python
n = n + 1
```
The key thing to understand is that **the code on the right side of the assignment operator, `=`,  runs first**. So Python first evaluates `n + 1`. We assigned `n` a value of `1`, so `n + 1` is equivalent to `1 + 1`, or `2`.

It then assigns the `2` as the new value of `n`:

```python
n = 2
```

So `n = n + 1` counts up by `1`!

This is an extremely common and useful technique that you will see used in programming all the time.

complex_prompt.text: Let's make sure this idea is solid. For each of these blocks of code, see if you can figure out what the final value of the variable would be.

concepts.text:
```python
count = 1
count = count + 1
count = count + 1
count = count + 1
```

atoms.text: OK, now we are ready to apply this to our goal‚Äîcounting the number of times a given character appears in a given string.

question.prompt:
Before we can start counting up, we have to assign the initial value of the `count` variable, like this:

```python
count = 0
```
Where do you think we should place that line in our code?

```python
for ch in "bonobos":
    if ch == "o":
        # Increase the count by one
```

tasks: Set the initial value of `count` to `0`.
`if` the current character is an `o`, increase `count` by `1`.
Finally, `print` the final value of `count`.
To run your code, open a new terminal and run `python3 counting_characters.py`.
atoms.positive_feedback:
**Woohoo!**

On the next page, we'll see how we can improve on this.
atoms.description:
Below is the code we started with on this page. See if you can finish it off so that it counts the number of times `o` appears in the string `"bonobos"`.

The code you add should do the following things:

atoms.text:
----

‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert!

 **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----

## Solution

```python
count = 0

for ch in "bonobos":
    if ch == "o":
        count = count + 1
        
print(count)
```

----

question.prompt:
To get the above code to work, we had to have the line `count = 0`. But why?

Try modifying the code to simply remove that line altogether:

```python
for ch in "bonobos":
    if ch == "o":
        count = count + 1
print(count)
```

Try this in the workspace. What result do you get?

atoms.text:
Can you see why we get this error?

It's because of the line `count = count + 1` . Python tries to evaluate the right side, `count + 1`. But we haven't set `count` to refer to anything yet, so Python doesn't know what this means. We have to give the variable an initial value before we can add to that value.

question.prompt:
OK, that explains why we need the line `count = 0`. But why does this line have to go *before* the loop, rather than *inside* the loop?

Go ahead and try putting it inside:

```python
for ch in "bonobos":
    count = 0
    if ch == "o":
        count = count + 1
print(count)
```

What result do you get now? (And can you guess at *why* this is happening?)

atoms.text:
So why does this happen?

It's because the line `count = 0` gets run *every time the loop runs*. So `count` keeps getting reset back to `0` over and over, rather than counting up like we want it to.

That is why we have to set the initial value of the `count` variable *before* the loop.

This is a common pattern that you will see in code, so keep it in mind!

# Counting things (2/2)

Our code from the last page works fine, but it's not very flexible‚Äîcurrently, it only checks for the letter `o` in a specific string (`"bonobos"`). If we wanted to check other characters and other strings, we would have to re-write the code each time.

Instead, it would be good to modify it so that we can give it *any* character and *any* string.

We did something similar in an earlier lesson, when we created some specific code for drawing a square‚Äîbut then decided it would be more useful if the code could draw any polygon. The solution in that case was to turn the code into a *function*‚Äîand that's the solution here as well.

tasks: Add a `def` statement for a function called `count_character`.
Add parameters for the string to be searched, and the character to count.
Use these parameters in the body of the function, in place of the hard-coded strings that are currently there.
Test your function with the provided `print` statements (you can add your own too, if you like!).
atoms.description: In the workspace below, you'll find the code from before. Your job is to turn it into a general function called `count_character`.

atoms.text:
----

‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert!

 **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----

## Solution

Here's our code:

```python

def count_character(string, target):
    count = 0
    for ch in string:
        if ch == target:
            count = count + 1
    return count

```

Yours may look different, such as if you chose different names for the function parameters.

----

# Indexing

We've seen that lists and strings have some things in common. Strings and lists both:
* Have a *length*.
* Are *sequences*.
* Can be *looped over*.

In this next video, Kelly briefly reviews these ideas, and then adds another thing that strings and lists have in common‚Äîsomething called **indexing**.

There may be a lot of words to describe it, but the underlying idea of *indexing* is simple: It's just a way to give a number to each item in a sequence, so that you can tell Python which item you're referring to.

It's no different from saying something like, "Hey Python, give me the fourth item in that list." or "Hey Python, give me the second character in that string."

Note that indexes start at `0`, not `1`. So the first item in a sequence would have an index of `0`, while the second would have an index of `1`, the third an index of `2`, and so on.

complex_prompt.text:
The best way to get comfortable with indexing is just to play with it a lot. This is a great example of how *interactive mode* is useful for trying out short pieces of code to see what they evaluate to.

Here are some examples you can try‚Äîfire up the Python interpreter and see what results you get.

And here are some more‚Äîwith lists this time, instead of strings.

> **Note:** It can be a little confusing that lists **and** the indexing operator both use square brackets `[ ]`. But the indexing operator will always come at the end, so you can tell it apart from a list by the context.

atoms.text:
## Negative indexes

You can also use negative numbers as indexes. If `word` is a string, then `word[-1]` is the _last_ character of that string, and `word[-2]` is the second-last, and so forth.

question.prompt:
If you wanted to get the letter `"s"` from this string ‚Äî
```python
word = "Fish"
```
‚Äî which expressions would do it?

There are **two** right answers here; mark **both** of them.

atoms.text: ## Indexing with comparisons

complex_prompt.text:
There are all kinds of ways we can combine indexing with other tools we've already learned. For example, here are some snippets of code that use indexing with the equality operator `==` to give a boolean value (`True` or `False`).


You can try these for yourself in interactive mode.

tasks: If you `print` out `start_K("Kelly")`, it should display `True`
If you `print` out `start_K("Abe")`, it should display `False`
atoms.description:
In the workspace below (or in your own code editor), write a function called `start_K` that checks whether a string starts with the letter `K`.

If the string starts with `K`, the function should return `True`. If it doesn't, the function should return `False`.

atoms.text:
----

‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert!

 **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----

## Solution

Here's one way to do it:

```python
def start_K(s):
    if s[0] == "K":
        return True
    else:
        return False
```

And here's another that's quite a bit shorter:

```python
def start_K(s):
    return s[0] == "K"
```
# The range function, revisited

Earlier, we used the `range` function with `for` loops. We saw that instead of using a list like this:

```python
for side in [0, 1, 2, 3]:
    amy.forward(100)
    amy.right(90)
```

We could use `range`:

```python
for side in range(4):
    amy.forward(100)
    amy.right(90)
```

There are a few things that the `range` function can do that we haven't explored‚Äîlet's check them out now.

question.prompt:
Now that we can print things to the terminal, we can print out the values that the range function is giving us. Go ahead and give this a try in your terminal:

```text
>>> for n in range(4):
...     print(n)
```

What do you see when you run the code?

atoms.text:
A key thing to remember about `range` is that when you pass it a number, it gives you back a sequence that goes **up to but does not include the number**. So `range(4)` provides a sequence that goes up to‚Äîbut does not include‚Äî`4`. You'll sometimes hear this described as an **exclusive** range, because the number you give is *excluded*.

Another thing you may remember about range is that it starts at `0`, not `1`. So `range[4]` is equivalent to `[0, 1, 2, 3]`.

Or at least, that's the default behavior ...

complex_prompt.text:
So far, we have only ever passed the `range` function *one* argument. But it turns out that it can accept up to *three* arguments. We'll talk about what each one does in a moment, but first, give them a try just to see what happens.

Here are some bits of code that you can try. What result do you get for each?

So we can pass `range` up to three arguments, like in the example we just tried:

```python
range(0, 10, 2)
```

Based on the results you got for this example, take a guess at what each of the three arguments is telling the `range` function to do.

correct_answer.text: Go up to (but don't include) this number.

answers.text: Go up to (but don't include) this number.

atoms.text:
Hopefully that gave you a feeling for what the three `range` parameters do:
* The first parameter is the number to **start** with.
* The second parameter is the number to **stop** at (or rather, to stop *before*, since it's excluded).
* The third parameter is the **step** size (i.e., how large a step to take when counting up).

Notice that **start** and **step** are optional‚Äîif you leave either (or both) out, the function will just go with the defaults‚Äîa start of `0` and a step of `1`.

complex_prompt.text: Here is a set of `range` calls. For each, match it with an equivalent call‚Äîthat is, one that looks different but would do the same thing.

atoms.text: # Length and indexing

We just learned about *indexing*, and also about how to get the length of a string using the `len` function. And previously, we used the `range` function with `for` loops. You've used each of these things separately, but it turns out that there are some things you can do by using them together. Let's play around and see what we can get...

complex_prompt.text:
Here are some different bits of code. Go ahead and try them (in the order shown here) in your own terminal.

As usual, it tends to help if you try to *predict* what each will do before you run it.

atoms.text:
As you can see, some of these bits of code seem to have the same result. For example, `range(3)` and `range(length(word))` did the same thing.

At this moment, this might seem kind of pointless. Why would we ever want to do `range(length(word))` instead of `range(3)`?

When we just look at these pieces of code by themselves, there is no reason for it. But we'll start putting these things together to form more complex code later.

If we just jumped directly into those more complex pieces of code, it might get confusing very quickly. So that's why it's important to look at these short snippets and get practice mentally recognizing what they do.

complex_prompt.text: And here are some more. As you can see, these are a little more complex.

concepts.text:
```text
>>> word = "yay"
>>> for n in range(len(word)):
...     print(n)
```

```text
>>> word = "yay"
>>> length = len(word)
>>> for n in range(length):
...     print(n)
```

```text
>>> word = "yay"
>>> length = len(word)
>>> for n in range(length):
...     print(word[n])
```

question.prompt:
Now give this a try:

```python
>>> word = "happy"
>>> for n in range(len(word)):
...    print(n, word[n])
```

answers.text: Printed the numbers `1` through `5`, each number on its own line.
Printed `0 h`, then `1 a`, `2 p`, and so forth: five lines, each with a number and letter.

atoms.text: Can you now see what `range(len(word))` does? It gives us a sequence of numbers that is exactly the same as the **index numbers** for the string. In other words, it gives us a way to loop over the index numbers of a string. This may not seem useful yet, but we will put it to use later in this lesson!

complex_prompt.text:
The key idea here is this: When we are using a string with a loop, *we can loop over two different things.* We can loop over the **characters** themselves, or we can loop over the **index numbers** for those characters.

See if you can match each of these pieces of code with what it is looping over.

question.prompt:
Here's one loop:

```text
>>> word = "yay"
>>> for n in range(len(word)):
...     print(word[n])
```

And here's another:

```text
>>> word = "yay"
>>> for ch in word:
...     print(ch)
```

Would these print out the same thing? Or different things?

answers.text: They print out the same thing.

atoms.text: Again, it may not be clear yet why it's useful to be able to loop over a string in these different ways. We'll come back to this a bit later in the lesson, and use it to do something more than simply print things.

complex_prompt.text:
Which line of code produces which kind of error?

(Assume that you just started Python and no new variables have been defined.)

atoms.text:
### 0Ô∏è‚É£ The empty string

A string with no characters in it is an **empty string**:
```
no_words = ""
```

question.prompt:
Create an empty string variable in the Python interpreter, and then try to index into it:
```python
no_words = ""
print(no_words[0])
```
What do you see?

answers.text: An error message: `IndexError: string index out of range`
No message at all; just the `>>>` prompt.
A ravenous wolf that devours your terminal.

atoms.text:
# IndexError

As you saw above, the `IndexError` message happens when you're trying to use an index to access a particular item, but *there is no item with that index*. In the above case, the code tries to access the character at index `0`, but there's no character with that index.

Here's another example of code that will cause an `IndexError`:

```
word = "dog"
for n in range(10):
  print(word[n])
```

The variable `n` will range from `0` up to `9` as the loop runs ... which means that the code will try to access `word[0]`, then `word[1]`, then `word[2]` ... then `word[3]`, which will crash with an `IndexError`.

question.prompt:
Which of these approaches would let you avoid `IndexError` when looping over a string?

(Assume the string variable is named `word`, as in the example above.)

Mark **all** the answers that are correct.

answers.text: Don't use indexing at all: just use `for char in word:`
Use the length of the string: `for n in range(len(word)):`
You can't; every loop over a string can always produce `IndexError`.

complex_prompt.text:
Here are some examples to play with.

See if you can predict what each will do before you try it for yourself.
And here are some more:

Now let's do something a little more complex.

Suppose that we first do this:
```text
>>> word = "definitely"
>>> length = len(word)
```

Now we have a string stored in the `word` variable, and we have the length of that string stored in the `length` variable. In this case, the length is `10`.

What result would you get from each of these expressions?

atoms.text:
## No Index Errors with slice operations

Slice operations _never_ cause `IndexError`. A slice that tries to extract characters off of the end of the string, will instead just return as much as it can get, even if that's nothing at all ‚Äî

```python
>>> "presto"[1024:4096]
''
```
This expression is asking for the characters from position 1024 to 4096 of a string that only has six characters. This definitely seems like the kind of thing that would give an Index Error, but Python just returns whatever it can get. In this case, it can't get *anything* at those locations, so it simply returns an empty string.
## Exercise: Word triangle

In the workspace below you'll find a partially completed `for` loop.

Your goal is to finish the loop so that it prints out the following:

```text
d
de
def
defi
defin
defini
definit
definite
definitel
definitely
```

----
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----

## Solution

Here's one way to do it:

```python
word = "definitely"
length = len(word)

for n in range(length):
    print(word[0:n + 1])
```

To see how this works, it might help if you add a line to also print the values of `n`:

```python
word = "definitely"
length = len(word)

for n in range(length):
    print(n) # Add this line
    print(word[0:n + 1])
```

Each time through the loop, `n` gets larger. So `[0:n]` is a slice expression that will start from the beginning of the string (at the character with index `0`) and go up until the character at index `n`. Since `n` is growing, the string that gets printed will also grow longer each time.

Notice that we have to add `+ 1`, because `n` starts at `0` and goes up to `9` (but we want it to start at `1` and go up to `10`).

# Slicing (2/2)

The exercise you just did is actually very similar to something people used to do with the word *abracadabra*...

## Abracadabra

The magic word **abracadabra** comes from an ancient superstition in which people would write the word in a triangular pattern, dropping one letter on each line, from `"abracadabra"` all the way down to `"a"`. The idea was, that as the _word_ disappeared, so too would bad luck disappear ‚Äî

atoms.caption: _"Abracadabra" triangle from an early Encyclop√¶dia Britannica_

atoms.text:
Today, we don't need magical inscriptions to make our strings vanish away to nothing ‚Äî¬†we can do it using `for` loops and slices!

Write a function `word_triangle` that takes a string as its argument, and prints out a triangle similar to the one above. You don't have to center it, though. Here's an example of what it should look like:

```python
>>> word_triangle("kitten")
kitten
kitte
kitt
kit
ki
k
```

This is very similar to the exercise you just did, but with some important differences:
1. We start with the full word, and remove letters from the end.
2. We're making it into a function so that it can be called with different words.

----
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----

## Solution

Here's one way to write the `word_triangle` function in the exercise above:

```python
def word_triangle(word):
  length = len(word)
  for n in range(length):
    print(word[:length - n])
```

The slice expression here is `word[:length - n]`. Since `length` stays the same while `n` grows, this means that on each pass through the loop, `length - n` gets smaller and smaller, from `length` down to `1`. And _that_ means that on each pass, the string that gets printed will be a shorter and shorter piece of `word`.

There are a lot of other ways to write this, too!

complex_prompt.text: Here are some different examples of expressions using **concatenation**. What would each of them evaluate to?

atoms.text:
## Exercise: Adverbly

In English, you can often form an adverb (such as *quickly*) by starting with an adjective (like *quick*) and adding "ly" to the end.

(In Silicon Valley, you can often form a _startup name_ by taking a noun or verb and adding "ly" to the end.)

Write a function called `adverbly` that takes a string as input and returns that string with `"ly"` appended to it.

----
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----

### Adverbly, solution

This one is quite short:
```python
def adverbly(s):
    return s + 'ly'
```
# Concatenation (2/2)
Here's something kind of fun we can do in the terminal using concatenation:

```text
What's your name?

Abe

Hi, Abe! It's very nice to meet you.

What's your favorite color?

vermillion

Ah, vermillion, what a lovely color!
```

The code for this uses the `input` function to get strings from the user, like their name and favorite color. It then uses the concatenation operator to construct some responses based on what the user entered.

tasks: Use the `input` function to get a response from the user, and assign the response to a variable.
Concatenate the user's response with another string, and print the result.
If you like, you can use `\n` in your strings to create line breaks.
atoms.description:
In the workspace below (or in the code editor on your own computer), write some code that does something similar to what is shown above.

Feel free to be creative‚Äîthe point is to get input from the user, concatenate it with some other strings, and print the result.

atoms.text:
----
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----

## Solution

Here's our code:

```python
name = input("What's your name?\n\n")
print("\nHi, " + name + "! It's very nice to meet you.\n")
color = input("What's your favorite color?\n\n")
print("\nAh, " + color + ", what a lovely color!")
```

# f-strings
In this next video, Karl will introduce *f-strings*. This is something that was added to Python in version 3.6‚Äîso in order for this to work on your own computer, you must be sure to have Python 3.6 or later. As a reminder, you can check which version you have by going to your terminal and entering:

```text
python3 --version
```

complex_prompt.text:
Suppose that we want to get the following string:

```text
'The aardwolf eats termites.'
```
Which of the following would give us this result?

atoms.text:
----
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----

## Solution

```python
name = input("What's your name?\n\n")
print(f"\nHi, {name}! It's very nice to meet you.\n")
color = input("What's your favorite color?\n\n")
print(f"\nAh, {color}, what a lovely color!")
```

atoms.title: Python: Strings to numbers to strings

complex_prompt.text:
Below are some examples of code that we ran in the Python interactive interpreter.

See if you can predict the results of each one (and of course, you can also try them out yourself!).

concepts.text:
```python
>>> n = input("Please enter a number: ")
Please enter a number: 2
>>> n * 2
```

```python
>>> n = input("Please enter a number: ")
Please enter a number: 2
>>> n + 2
```

```python
>>> n = input("Please enter a number: ")
Please enter a number: 2
>>> int(n) + 2
```

```python
>>> n = int(input("Please enter a number: "))
Please enter a number: 2
>>> n + 2
```

complex_prompt.text:
Suppose that we have a number stored in a variable:

```python
>>> n = 7
```
And we want to generate a string like this:

```text
'The lucky number is 7.'
```

Below are some attempts at getting this result in the Python interpreter. Which of these would work?

tasks: To see a demo of how the program should work, open a new terminal and run `python3 demo.py`.
Use `input` to get the numbers, and assign them to variables (we called our variables `n1`, `n2`, and `n3`).
Use `int()` to convert the responses to integers, and then sum them up.
Print out the final message. We suggest using *f-strings* to put it all together.
atoms.description:
In this next exercise, your goal is to write a program that asks the user for three numbers, adds those numbers up, and then prints a message saying what the sum is. Like this:

```text
Enter a number: 2
Enter another number: 1
Enter a third number: 3
2 + 1 + 3 = 6
```

atoms.text:
----
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----

### Solution

Here's one way to do it:

```python
n1 = input("Enter a number: ")
n2 = input("Enter another number: ")
n3 = input("Enter a third number: ")
sum = int(n1) + int(n2) + int(n3)
print(f"{n1} + {n2} + {n3} = {sum}")
```

But there are other variations that would also work! For example, instead of *f-strings*, this version uses concatenation, along with the `str` function:

```python
n1 = input("Enter a number: ")
n2 = input("Enter another number: ")
n3 = input("Enter a third number: ")
sum = int(n1) + int(n2) + int(n3)
print(n1 + ' + ' + n2 + ' + ' + n3 + ' = ' + str(sum))
```

That's a little harder to read though!
# `starts_with` (1/3)

A little earlier in the course, we made a function called `start_K` that checks if a given string starts with `"K"`:

```python
def start_K(s):
    return s[0] == "K"
```

This function is so specific that it's not likely to be useful for much. It would be better if it could check for more than just `"K"`. Over the next couple of pages, we'll work on making the function more flexible. We'll also work toward a version of it that compares more than just a single letter.

## Just comparing the first letter

Our first goal will be as follows:

>Create a function called `starts_with` that takes two strings, and indicates whether the first characters of those strings match. In other words, it would do something like this:

```python
>>> starts_with("apple", "art")
True
>>> starts_with("apple", "cart")
False
```

complex_prompt.text:
Suppose we have the two strings we want to compare, and we assign them to some variables like so:

```python
s1 = "zebonkey"
s2 = "kiwi"
```
Our goal is to compare the characters in the **first** position (`"z"` and `"k"`). Which of these pieces of code will do that?

**Note:** Remember, the `!=` is the *not equal* comparison operator.

tasks: Define a function with two parameters (for the two strings).
Compare the first characters of the strings.
If the characters are the same, return `True`, otherwise return `False`.
Remove the comments from the `print` statements and run `python3 starts_with.py` to test your code.
atoms.description: OK, let's get to it! In the workspace below, define a function, `starts_with`, that takes two strings and compares the first character.

complex_prompt.text:
Here are some other attempts at the above solution.

For each, indicate whether it would do the same thing as the solution above, or if it would have a different result.

concepts.text:
```python
def starts_with(s1, s2):
    return s1[0] == s2[0]
```

```python
def starts_with(s1, s2):
    return s1[0] != s2[0]
```

atoms.text: # `starts_with` (2/3)

Let's move beyond just comparing the first letter. Instead, suppose that we have two strings‚Äîa **long** string and a **short** string‚Äîand we want to check whether the long string starts with the short string.

In other words, we want a function that does this:

```python
>>> starts_with("apple", "app")
True
>>> starts_with("banana", "ban")
True
>>> starts_with("manatee", "mango")
False
```

That will be our goal on this page:

>Write a function called `starts_with` that takes two strings as arguments, and returns `True` if the first string starts with the second string, and `False` otherwise.

## Checking all the positions

Our current version of the function just compares the letters at the *first* index position‚Äîthat is, position `0`. For example:


```python
"manatee"[0] == "manx"[0]
```

But now we want to go through **all** of the positions in the shorter string, not just position `0`.

To accomplish our goal, we need to loop over all of the **index positions** in the shorter string. Do you remember how we looped over a string's index positions? We looked at this earlier in the lesson, but it's kind of tricky, so let's check to be sure we've got it straight...

question.prompt: Assume that we've assigned the short string to a parameter called `short`. Which of these pieces of code would loop over all of the **index positions** in the `short` string?

complex_prompt.text:
Now that we have a `for` loop that cycles through the index positions, we can use an `if` test to check the characters at each position.

Specifically, we want to return `False` for the first pair of characters that does **not** match.

Here are some attempts to do that. Which of them would work?

tasks: Define a function with two parameters, `long` and `short`.
Create a `for` loop that loops over the *index numbers* of the `short` string.
For each index number, compare the characters at that position.
As soon as there's a pair that does **not** match, return `False`.
If the loop finishes (all characters match), return `True`.
atoms.description:
OK, it's time to put it all together and write the whole function! Here's the goal again, as a reminder:

>Write a function called `starts_with` that takes two strings as arguments, and returns `True` if the first string starts with the second string, and `False` otherwise.

Remember that the solution is available if you need it!

atoms.text:
----
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----
# `starts_with` (3/3)

In programming, there's almost always more than one way to do something. Here's an alternative approach to the `starts_with` function that's quite different: Instead of using a `for` loop and checking each pair of characters, we can simply use *string slicing*.

complex_prompt.text:
To see what we mean, open the Python interpreter. First, define these variables:

```python
>>> long = "banana"
>>> short = "ban"
```

 Then, give these bits of code a try. What results do you get?

tasks: Define a function with two parameters (`long` and `short`) just like before.
Use the slice operator `[:]` with the `len` function to get the first part of the `long` string.
If that slice matches the `short` string, return `True`. Otherwise, return `False`.
atoms.description: Now, give it a try! See if you can write an alternative version of the `starts_with` function that uses string slicing.

atoms.text:
----
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----

## Solution

Here's one way to do it:

```python
def starts_with(long, short):
    if long[0:len(short)] == short:
        return True
    else:
        return False
```

Or, as before, we can shorten this to a single return statement:

```python
def starts_with(long, short):
    return long[0:len(short)] == short
```
In this next video, Kelly will walk through the different solutions for `starts_with` that we covered on the last couple of pages.

atoms.title: IPND PY L4 13 Starts With Impl HS ANIM FIXES V2

atoms.text:
## Differences in the three versions

Like Kelly said, there *are* some differences in how these different versions work.

Here are all three versions in one place, for your reference:

```
def starts_with_v1(long, short):
    for position in range(len(short)):
        if long[position] != short[position]:
            return False
    return True
```

```
def starts_with_v2(long, short):
    length = len(short)
    beginning = long[0 : length]
    if beginning == short:
        return True
    else:
        return False
```

```
def starts_with_v3(long, short):
    return long[0:len(short)] == short
```
These all do the same thing with normal input, but they do different things if the input is a little bit off. For instance, what happens if you pass a `long` string that is actually shorter than the `short` string, e.g.: `starts_with_v1("tin", "tinkerbell")`?

question.prompt:
Copy the three functions above into your Python interpreter, then run these lines of code. Note that in each one, the `long` argument is shorter than the `short` argument.

```python
starts_with_v1("tin", "tinkerbell")
starts_with_v2("tin", "tinkerbell")
starts_with_v3("tin", "tinkerbell")
```
What differences do you see between the behavior of these three functions?

answers.text: The first one produces an `IndexError`, while the others just return `False`.
The first two produce an `IndexError`, while the third returns `False`.
The first one returns `True`, the second produces `IndexError`, and the third produces `SliceError`.
There is no difference between them.

atoms.text: # `" ".`  Methods on strings

## The `startswith` method

We had you go through the process of writing the `starts_with` function because we wanted you to have an understanding of how a function like that might work.

But checking if one string starts with another is pretty common in programming, so Python actually comes with the feature built in!

Specifically, it is available as a built-in *method* called `startswith`. Remember, a **method** is simply a function that is associated with a specific object. Like when we used turtles earlier, the `forward` method was always associated with a specific turtle, as in `amy.forward(100)`.

tasks: Go ahead and try the `startswith` method in your own terminal.
atoms.description:
Here's how you would use the `startswith` method:

```python
>>> "banana".startswith("ban")
True
>>> "bonobo".startswith("ban")
False
```

atoms.text: >**Note:** If you feel like you just went through a whole bunch of work creating the `starts_with` function for nothing... well, that's kind of the point! This is the whole reason for built-in functions‚Äîto save you the work of creating functions for commonly needed tasks.

## String predicates

There are a lot of methods you can use on strings. You can find a full list of them [in the Python documentation](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#string-methods).

Many string methods, like `startswith` and `endswith`, are **predicates** ‚Äî which means that they return `True` or `False` to indicate something about the string.

You can use predicates in `if` statements. For example, here's some code that checks a string for angle brackets (like you would see in an HTML tag):

```python
def possible_tag(word):
    if word.startswith("<") and word.endswith(">"):
        print(word, "could maybe be an HTML tag")
    else:
        print(word, "is definitely not an HTML tag (but might contain one)")
```

complex_prompt.text: Take a look through the [list of string methods](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#string-methods) in the Python documentation. Look for predicates ‚Äî methods that return `True` or `False` ‚Äî¬†to answer each of these questions:

concepts.text: Is this string made of only digits?
Is this string made of only lowercase letters?
Is this string made of only whitespace characters, such as spaces and tabs?

complex_prompt.text:
Here are the examples Kelly showed at the end of the video. Start up the Python interactive interpreter and see what each of them evaluates to.

Here are the expressions using the `and` operator:
And here are the expressions using the `or` operator:

atoms.text:
Is all of that `True` and `False` business getting jumbled in your head? If so, it's probably because it's pretty abstract. There aren't many situations where you would actually want to have code like this:

```python
True and True
```

Instead, you would have code that looks more like this:

```python
2 == 2 and 5 == 5
```

Since `2 == 2` evaluates to `True`, and `5 == 5` also evaluates to `True`, this whole thing evaluates to:

```python
True and True
```

Which would then evaluate to simply:

```python
True
```

complex_prompt.text: Here are some more examples you can try out in the interpreter:

tasks: Define a function (we called ours `good_length`) with one parameter (for the string to check).
The function should return `True` if the string is between `8` and `64` characters long, and `False` otherwise.
atoms.description: Many web services want users to have passwords that are at least eight characters long, but it can be a problem if passwords are _too_ long. Your goal will be to write a function that checks any given string to see if it's a good length.

atoms.text:
----
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Spoiler alert! **Our solution is below.** You'll learn more effectively if you give the exercise a strong effort before comparing your code with ours!
---- ----

## Solution

```python
def good_length(s):
    return len(s) > 8 and len(s) < 64
```

## The `not` operation

There is a third boolean operation called `not`:

* `not x` is true if `x` is false.
* `not x` is false if `x` is true.

An interesting consequence of these rules is that `not (x and y)` is the same as `(not x) or (not y)`. Similarly, `not (x or y)` is the same as `(not x) and (not y)`.
